cmCourseInfo.description: Intended for students with no background in Mandarin or any Chinese dialect, this course provides an introduction to modern standard Chinese as a foreign/second language. The course consists of mandatory lectures and tutorials. Students study a minimum of 550 Chinese characters. Students must go through screening process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/chinese for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Standard Chinese I
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: EAS101Y1, LGGA60H3, LGGA61H3, LGGB60H3, LGGB61H3, CHI100Y5, CHI101H5

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Students must register on ACORN and submit the EAS100Y Screening Form online: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/chinese/ Failure to submit the form by August 15 will result in removal from the course.

courses.name: Modern Chinese I for Students with Prior Background

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed for students who understand elementary Mandarin or any Chinese dialect because of their cultural or family backgrounds. The course consists of mandatory lectures and tutorials. Students will learn a minimum of 650 characters. Students must go through placement process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/chinese for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Chinese I for Students with Prior Background
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: EAS100Y1, EAS200Y1, LGGA60H3, LGGA61H3, LGGB60H3, LGGB61H3, CHI100Y5, CHI101H5, CHI200Y5, CHI201Y5

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
In order to request enrolment in this course students must attend an interview. Returning students should attend an interview in April; incoming students in September before classes begin. For more information and to register for the interview: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/chinese/

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines how various histories of East Asia can be written by focusing on specific themes in the histories of China, Japan, and Korea to roughly 1600. Required of EAS specialists, majors, and minors.
cmCourseInfo.title: Premodern East Asia

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: December 6, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines how various histories of East Asia can be written by focusing on specific themes in the histories of China, Japan, and Korea from roughly 1600 to the Cold War. Required of EAS specialists, majors, and minors.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern East Asia

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed to help students build communication skills in the Korean language. Through an integration of listening, speaking, reading and writing, it aims to provide a solid foundation in beginning-level Korean. This course assumes that students do not have any prior knowledge of Korean. Students must go through screening process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/korean for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Standard Korean I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Students must register on ACORN and submit the EAS110Y Screening Form online: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/korean/ Failure to submit the form by August 15 will result in removal from the course. Students in LEC0101 must register in TUT0101 or TUT0201. Students in LEC0201 must register in TUT0301 or TUT0401. There are no exceptions. If you cannot register for and attend a tutorial that corresponds to your lecture, you may not take the course and will be removed. For more info, please contact natasja.vanderberg@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is for students with no or a very limited background in Japanese. Students must go through screening process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/japanese/ for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Standard Japanese I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Students must register on ACORN and submit the EAS120Y Screening Form online: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/japanese/. Failure to submit the form by August 15 will result in removal from the course. Students in L0101 must register for an attend one of the following tutorials: T0101, T0201, T0401, T0501, T0602. Students in L0201 must register for an attend one of the following tutorials: T0301, T0402, T0601, T0701, T5101. There are no exceptions. If you cannot register for or attend a tutorial that corresponds to your lecture, you may not take the course and will be removed. For more info, please contact natasja.vanderberg@utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Japanese I for Students with Prior Background

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is equivalent to the second half of EAS120Y1 for students with some background in the Japanese language. Students must go through placement process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/japanese/ for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Japanese I for Students with Prior Background

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
In order to request enrolment in this course students must write the Japanese Placement Test. Returning students should write the test in April; incoming students in September. For more information and to register: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/japanese/

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is a continuation of EAS100Y1. Students learn major grammatical structures which are not introduced in the first year and expand their vocabulary. Students who do not meet the prerequisite must go through a placement process conducted by the Department. See eas.utoronto.ca/languages/chinese for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Standard Chinese II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: EAS100Y1 (minimum grade 67%)/equivalent as determined by placement process.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: EAS101Y1, EAS201H1, LGGB60H3, LGGB61H3, CHI200Y5, CHI201Y5

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For enrolment instructions, please see: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/chinese/ In order to request enrolment in this course students without the prerequisite must attend an interview. Returning students should attend an interview in April; incoming students in September.

courses.name: Modern Chinese II for Students with Prior Background (formerly EAS201Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is a continuation of EAS101Y1. It focuses on development of students listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills at a low intermediate level. Students who do not meet the prerequisite must go through placement process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/chinese for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Chinese II for Students with Prior Background (formerly EAS201Y1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: EAS101Y1 (minimum 67%)/equivalent as determined by placement process.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: EAS200Y1, EAS201Y1, EAS290Y1, LGGB60H3, LGGB61H3, CHI200Y5, CHI201Y5

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For enrolment instructions, please see: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/chinese/ In order to request enrolment in this course students without the prerequisite must attend an interview. Returning students should attend an interview in April; incoming students in September.

cmCourseInfo.description: Required of EAS specialists and majors, this course introduces various approaches, theories, and methodologies for the study of East Asian societies and cultures. As the course serves as a foundation for upper-level EAS courses, it should be taken as early as possible, preferably in the second year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Approaches to East Asia (formerly EAS209Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: As a continuation of EAS110Y1, this course is designed to help students improve their skills in the Korean language. Students in this course are expected to perform basic communicative functions, read and write paragraph-level texts, and conjugate verbs/adjectives accurately. Students who do not meet the prerequisite must go through placement process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/korean for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Standard Korean II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: EAS110Y1 (63% minimum)/equivalent as determined by the Korean placement interview

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For enrolment instructions, please see: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/korean/ In order to request enrolment in this course students without the prerequisite must write the Korean Placement Test. Returning students should write the test in April; incoming students in September.

courses.name: Accelerated Modern Standard Korean I & II

cmCourseInfo.description: Covering both EAS110Y1 and EAS210Y1, the course is ideal for self-motivated students who enjoy fast-paced language learning, students with a passion for Korean films and television, students with some listening and speaking skills from prior study or family background, and students taking the full four-year course series. Successful completion of the course fulfils the prerequisite for EAS310Y1. Students must go through screening process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/korean for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Accelerated Modern Standard Korean I & II

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Students must register on ACORN and submit the EAS211Y Screening Form online: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/korean/ Failure to submit the form by August 15 will result in removal from the course.

cmCourseInfo.description: As a continuation of EAS110Y1, this course is designed to help students increase their Korean communication skills at beginner high to intermediate low levels. It is ideal for self-motivated students who enjoy fast-paced language learning, and students who have built basic language skills from prior study. Successful completion of the course fulfils the prerequisite for EAS310Y1. Students must go through screening process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/korean for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Accelerated Modern Standard Korean II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: EAS110Y1 (70% minimum)/equivalent as determined by the Korean placement process.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For enrolment instructions, please see: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/korean/ In order to request enrolment in this course students without the prerequisite must write the Korean Placement Test. Returning students should write the test in April; incoming students in September.

courses.name: Cultural History of Food in East Asia

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces historical, literary, and anthropological issues related to the consumption of food in East Asia. Through a wide variety of reading materials, it focuses on the relationship between various foodways and trade, ritual, religion, medicine, and cultural identity.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cultural History of Food in East Asia

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: December 5, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: This is an advanced beginner level language course for those who completed EAS120Y1 or EAS121H1 with a minimum grade of 67%. Students who do not meet the prerequisite must go through placement process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/japanese/ for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Standard Japanese II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: EAS120Y1/EAS121H1 (minimum 67%)/equivalent as determined by placement process

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For enrolment instructions, please see: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/japanese/ In order to request enrolment in this course students without the prerequisite must write the Japanese Placement Test. Returning students should write the test in April; incoming students in September.

courses.name: Modern Standard Japanese II for Students with Prior Background

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: December 5, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is equivalent to the second half of EAS220Y1. Designed for those who have a good foundation of lower beginners grammar, vocabulary, and kanji knowledge and have not yet acquired the proficiency required to take EAS320Y1. Students must go through placement process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/japanese for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Standard Japanese II for Students with Prior Background
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: The first half of the content covered in EAS220Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
In order to request enrolment in this course students must write the Japanese Placement Test. Returning students should write the test in April; incoming students in September. For more information and to register: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/japanese/

cmCourseInfo.description: The course introduces the major philosophical traditions in China, such as Confucianism, Daoism, and Buddhism, and their historical development from ancient to modern times in four periods: the emergence of Confucianism, Daoism, and other minor schools; the introduction of Buddhism and the development of various sects of Chinese Mahayana Buddhism; the unfolding of neo-Confucianism; and the development of modern Chinese philosophy.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of Chinese Philosophy

courses.name: Japanese Cinemas I: Film Form and the Problems of Modernity

cmCourseInfo.description: This course investigates how film aesthetics relate to the most profound socio-historical problems of Japanese modernity. It also considers the ways various filmmakers employ cinematic form to engage the social problems of their moment. Part I focuses on the 1890s - 1950s.
cmCourseInfo.title: Japanese Cinemas I: Film Form and the Problems of Modernity

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Course added: June 22, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the history of Japan from about 1600 until the disintegration of the Tokugawa regime in the mid-19th century. Uses a wide range of translated primary Japanese texts to illuminate the emergence of cultural forms and their conjunction with social, economic, religious, and political trends.
cmCourseInfo.title: Early Modern Japanese History

courses.name: History of Capitalism in Modern Japan

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides a historical narrative of the development of the capitalist mode of production in Japan, from the mid-19th century to the present day. Readings include texts from various disciplines: economics, philosophy, social and labour history, and literature.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of Capitalism in Modern Japan

courses.name: Aesthetics and Politics in 20th Century Korea

cmCourseInfo.description: This lecture course examines key questions and texts in the history of literature from the Korean peninsula during the twentieth century, exploring how aesthetic form refracted the experiences of colonialism, division, and the formation of opposing nation-states.
cmCourseInfo.title: Aesthetics and Politics in 20th Century Korea

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of major works in premodern Chinese literature, including poetry, essays, and short narratives from the pre-Qin through Tang eras (11th century BCE - 10th century CE).
cmCourseInfo.title: Chinese Literature (Pre-Qin to Tang) (formerly EAS336H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of major works in premodern Chinese literature, including poetry, essays, short narratives and drama from the Song through Qing dynasties (10th - 19th centuries CE).
cmCourseInfo.title: Chinese Literature (Song to Qing) (formerly EAS337H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the history of Korea from the Tonghak uprising and Sino-Japanese war of 1894-1895, through the colonial period, division, and to the civil war.
cmCourseInfo.title: 20th Century Korean History

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers a critical review of the history and historiography of modern Chinese cities. Focusing on the development of specific Chinese cities, the course emphasizes understanding the socio-cultural production of space as well as analytical reading of landscape, urban imagery, and urban writings.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Chinese Cities

cmCourseInfo.description: Through various forms of popular culture in the 20th century, this course explores the cultural contexts and social trajectories of China, Japan and Korea. Forms of popular culture studied include art, visual culture, consumer habits, foodways, advertising, music, and fashion.
cmCourseInfo.title: Popular Culture in East Asia

cmCourseInfo.description: The course examines the ethical, political, historic and aesthetic dimensions of Asian Ecocinema (environmental films that engage with the Asia-based global environmental crisis) and discusses the films ways of connecting place and planet.
cmCourseInfo.title: East Asian Ecocinema

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers a critical examination of 20th-century Chinese literature, with a focus on the important developments of literary writing over time, from the inception of New Literature in the 1910s, the development of realism and modernism in the 1930s, to the emergency of post-revolution and postmodernist writings in the 1990s. Emphasis is placed on generating a dialogue on interpretations of key works.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Chinese Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: This high intermediate-level course is a continuation of EAS200Y. Students learn to read short texts which deal with personal or social topics, compose paragraph-length essays, and converse in social situations which require exchanges of basic information. Students who do not meet the prerequisite must go through placement process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/chinese for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Standard Chinese III
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: EAS200Y1 (EAS200Y1 (minimum 70%)/EAS201Y1 or EAS201H1 (minimum 70%)/equivalent as determined by placement process.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: EAS290Y1, LGGC60H3, LGGC61H3, LGGC62H3, LGGC63H3, CHI301Y5, CHI310Y5, CHI311Y5

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For enrolment instructions, please see: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/chinese/ In order to request enrolment in this course students without the prerequisite must attend an interview. Returning students should attend an interview in April; incoming students in September.

cmCourseInfo.description: The course analyses the development of Chinese political philosophy from ancient times to the present day, focusing on Confucianism, Daoism, and Legalism and their relation to issues in political philosophy today.
cmCourseInfo.title: Chinese Political Philosophy

courses.name: East Asia Seen in Maps, Ancient and Modern

cmCourseInfo.description: Through the lens of important maps ancient and new, this course looks at the histories, cultural logic, and methods of visual representation in societies of East Asia. The maps include archaeological artifacts, ancient manuscripts, and printed renditions, spanning from early history to the nineteenth century.
cmCourseInfo.title: East Asia Seen in Maps, Ancient and Modern

cmCourseInfo.description: As a continuation of EAS210Y1 and EAS211Y1, this course is designed to help students improve their Korean proficiency at the intermediate level. The class focuses not only on oral fluency and grammar but also on reading comprehension. Students who do not meet the prerequisite must go through placement process conducted by Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/korean for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Standard Korean III
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: EAS210Y1/EAS211Y1/EAS212H1 (67% minimum)/equivalent as determined by placement process

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For enrolment instructions, please see: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/korean/ In order to request enrolment in this course students without the prerequisite must write the Korean Placement Test. Returning students should write the test in April; incoming students in September.

courses.name: Art and Archaeology of Early China

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores ancient societies from prehistory to the Bronze Age of China from archaeological perspectives with a focus on Chinese collections at the ROM. The course offers students an understanding of the origins and formation of Chinese civilizations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Art and Archaeology of Early China

cmCourseInfo.description: This is a lower intermediate level course for those who have completed EAS220Y1 with a minimum grade of 70%. Students who do not meet the prerequisite must go through placement process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/japanese/ for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Standard Japanese III
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: EAS220Y1 (70% minimum)/equivalent as determined by placement process

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For enrolment instructions, please see: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/japanese/ In order to request enrolment in this course students without the prerequisite must write the Japanese Placement Test. Returning students should write the test in April; incoming students in September.

courses.name: Science, Technology and Society in Modern China

cmCourseInfo.description: Learn to understand modern China from an understudied yet important perspective: the development of science and technology since the establishment of Peoples Republic in 1949. Science and technology have played crucial parts in Chinas political, economical, social, and cultural transformations. Drawing from anthropological, social, and historical studies of science, we examine, among other topics, science and nation-building, biopolitics, technocracy, and scientists self-fashioning at the junction of Communist reign and global capitalism. Students also learn key concepts of science studies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Science, Technology and Society in Modern China

cmCourseInfo.description: The history of modern Japan as revealed by the problem of everyday life and its relationship to capitalism. Using a range of literary, philosophical, economic, and ethnographic materials that deal with the development of capitalism in Japan, Japanese colonialism, imperialism, and fascism, the course explores ways to specify and critique what is called everyday life.
cmCourseInfo.title: Everyday Life in Modern Japan

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to sound studies through the case of modern China. The class surveys basic theories of sound studies. It investigates the technological, cultural, and social production of soundscapes in modern China. Topics include the invention of national language(s), the introduction of gramophone, radio, and sound cinema, and the relationship between sound, aesthetics, and power.
cmCourseInfo.title: Soundscapes and Modern China

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Time changed: June 22, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the Classical Chinese language with emphasis on grammatical analysis and translation into English. Open only to EAS majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Classical Chinese I
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: two or more years of Modern Standard Chinese

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room changed: September 20, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to classical Japanese, followed by readings of various short works by classical authors. Covers first half of EAS362Y1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Classical Japanese Part I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Students who have background in Japanese who would like to request to take this course without the prerequisite should contact EAS's Program Administrator, Natasja VanderBerg (natasja.vanderberg@utoronto.ca). Please do so before mid-July in case you must take the Japanese Placement Test or the prerequisite course.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 18, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to classical Japanese, followed by readings of various short works by classical authors. Covers the second half of EAS362Y1. Students must seek permission of the instructor to be placed in the course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Classical Japanese Part II

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Students who have some background in Classical Japanese who would like to request to take this course without the prerequisite should contact EAS's Program Administrator, Natasja VanderBerg (natasja.vanderberg@utoronto.ca). Please do so before mid-July in case you must take the Japanese Placement Test or the prerequisite course.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: December 14, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: Topics vary according to the instructors interests.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Buddhism

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: December 14, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: This course discusses documentary film and DV culture in contemporary China as forms of cultural, communal, and political practices. We focus on films and videos that seek to address important global issues such as peace, environment, and climate change in cross-media approach and in personal tone. We ask: What new tendencies are there in the films and videos? Where can we trace them back to? What fresh possibilities do they bring forth to our aesthetic and public life?
cmCourseInfo.title: Film Culture in Contemporary China

cmCourseInfo.description: This course aims to develop students abilities at an advanced level, with a focus on reading of fictional and/or journalistic writings. Students will improve their reading comprehension, strengthen writing skills, and advance speaking and listening skills through class discussions and oral presentations. Students who do not meet the prerequisite must go through placement process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/chinese for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Standard Chinese IVa
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: EAS300Y1 (minimum 73%)/EAS402H1 (minimum 73%)/equivalent as determined by placement process

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For enrolment instructions, please see: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/chinese/ In order to request enrolment in this course students without the prerequisite must attend an interview. Returning students should attend an interview in April; incoming students in September.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course aims to develop students language abilities at an advanced level, with a focus on reading argumentative-style essays and news. Students will improve their reading comprehension, strengthen writing skills, and advance speaking and listening skills through class discussions and oral presentations. Students who do not meet the prerequisite must go through placement process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/chinese for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Standard Chinese IVb
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: EAS300Y1 (minimum 73%)/EAS401H1 (minimum 73%)/equivalent as determined by placement process

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For enrolment instructions, please see: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/chinese/ In order to request enrolment in this course students without the prerequisite must attend an interview. Returning students should attend an interview in April; incoming students in September.

courses.name: Textual Analysis of Classical Chinese Philosophy

cmCourseInfo.description: Readings from ancient and medieval Chinese philosophy. Beginning with linguistic (especially semantic) analysis of key words, structure and meaning of sentences, paragraphs, and texts as a whole, which forms the basis for philosophical examination.
cmCourseInfo.title: Textual Analysis of Classical Chinese Philosophy

cmCourseInfo.description: A general survey of modern Taiwanese literature from 1949 to the present. It examines issues central to understanding the Taiwanese literary culture, such as historical/cultural context, oral/written language, self-identification, gender, and human rights.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Taiwanese Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: As a continuation of EAS310Y1, this course is designed for advanced-level learners of Korean. Through reading short essays/articles and watching films, this course aims to improve students proficiency in speaking, writing, listening, and reading. Classroom and online discussions are conducted entirely in Korean. Students who do not meet the prerequisite must go through placement process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/korean for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Standard Korean IV
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: EAS310Y1 (70% minimum)/equivalent as determined by placement process

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For enrolment instructions, please see: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/korean/ In order to request enrolment in this course students without the prerequisite must write the Korean Placement Test. Returning students should write the test in April; incoming students in September.

courses.name: Technology and Material Cultures of Ancient China

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces the technology and material culture of prehistoric and Bronze-Age China. Offers students an understanding of the development of ancient technologies (e.g. bronze, jade, and lacquer) and associated ways of life from archaeological perspectives.
cmCourseInfo.title: Technology and Material Cultures of Ancient China

courses.name: Chinese Cultural Studies Seminar: May Fourth

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar focuses on the May Fourth Movement in early twentieth century China. Taking May Fourth as a case study and a vantage point, this class enables a critical understanding of various aspects of the cultural and intellectual life in the early Republican period.
cmCourseInfo.title: Chinese Cultural Studies Seminar: May Fourth

cmCourseInfo.description: A scholarly project chosen by the student, approved by the Department, and supervised by one of its instructors. Consult the website (eas.utoronto.ca) for more information. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

To enrol in this course, please contact Natasja VanderBerg, the Program Administrator, at natasja.vanderberg@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: A scholarly project chosen by the student, approved by the Department, and supervised by one of its instructors. Consult the website (eas.utoronto.ca) for more information. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar explores the growing field of sound studies with particular attention given to auditory histories and cultures in modern Japan and the prewar Japanese empire in East Asia. We study the interrelationships between industrialization, mass culture, colonialism, and techniques and processes of reproducing sound in order to specify the status of acoustic and sonic mediation in everyday life in a capitalist commodity economy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sound Studies and Modern Japan

cmCourseInfo.description: Examination of how the future is imagined and materialized in architectural theory and practice throughout Japanese history. From classical temples to modernist experiments of the Metabolist movement to contemporary works by Isozaki Arata and Atelier Bow Wow, we study built and unbuilt structures as theories of the future.
cmCourseInfo.title: Future, Architecture, Japan

cmCourseInfo.description: This is a high intermediate level Japanese course that focuses on oral/aural communication. Native or near-native speakers are not permitted to take this course. Students who do not meet the prerequisite must go through placement process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/japanese for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Standard Japanese IVa
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: EAS320Y1 (70% minimum)/equivalent as determined by placement process

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For enrolment instructions, please see: http://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/japanese/ In order to request enrolment in this course students without the prerequisite must write the Japanese Placement Test. Returning students should write the test in April; incoming students in September.

cmCourseInfo.description: This is a high intermediate level Japanese course that focuses on reading and writing skills. Native or near-native speakers are not permitted to take this course. Students who do not meet the prerequisite must go through placement process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/japanese for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Standard Japanese IVb
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: EAS320Y (70% minimum)/equivalent as determined by placement process

notes.name: Course Note

courses.name: History, Everyday Life, and North Korea

cmCourseInfo.description: This essay-driven course explores the complexity of examining North Korean history by using comparative methods developed through the study of other socialist societies and theories of everyday life.
cmCourseInfo.title: History, Everyday Life, and North Korea

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Instructor permission to enrol in the course. Students must have taken EAS209H1 and EAS271H1 and have a high GPA as you will be meeting with graduate students. Please email EAS’s Undergraduate Administrator at natasja.vanderberg@utoronto.ca by July 31, 2017 to request permission.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in East Asian Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth study of Chinese, Japanese or Korean culture, history and/or literature. Content depends on the instructor.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in East Asian Studies
